Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining> @zpajk lol 'haraka 2 heavy'

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Crupti> @zpajk There is a lot going on in the Verus hashing algo, but I think the most heavy innerloop happens in __verusclmulwithoutreduction64alignedrepeat() , see https://github.com/VerusCoin/nheqminer/blob/master/nheqminer/crypto/verus_clhash.cpp  for the code. There is a lot of haraka stuff happening too, but only one Haraka per inner hash and one call to __verusclmulwithoutreduction64alignedrepeat() which is where most of the heavy CPU happens. They use a lot of Intel SIMD intrinic functions, which are basically integrated functionality inside newer (2012 and later usually) CPUs - these functions are super efficient on the CPU which is why CPUs are better than GPUs on Verus.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Crupti> @zpajk Per hash there is (simplified explanation, mind you ðŸ˜ƒ ) first a Haraka 512 with a zero roundkey, then a call to verusclmulwithoutreduction64alignedrepeat() which has a heavy loop with 32 iterations (see the link) and then there is a second Haraka 512 with a rondkey that uses the hash writer buffer. There are other stuff going on with VerusHash per hash, but that's the heavy stuff I think. @Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining can correct me if I'm wrong ðŸ˜ƒ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining> u missed out. after the first 512haraka hash on the header from the pool. the large mutating round key is created by chaining together 522 x haraka256 hashes to fill it up

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining> but the large key can be used many times as it's before the nonce is applied

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Crupti> @Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining Yes, but the initial stuff is done only once, that's why I left that part out from my explanation.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Crupti> The initial building is done only once per job, then there are 1 million hashes, each of these hashes has 1) haraka 512 with zero roundkey, 2) call to verusclmulwithoutreduction64alignedrepeat() , and then 3) call to haraka 512 using the hashwriter buffer as a roundkey. Something like that ... ðŸ˜ƒ

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining> the first haraka zero is only Done once

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Crupti> Ok

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining> each hash starts with the same round key.  same haraka 512 zero final hash

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining> that's what's transferred to the gpu on gpu miner

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Crupti> I though you had to run Haraka 512 with a zero roundkey at the start of every hash on the current hash. I'll look into it again.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining> no

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining> it's just done to create a 512bit hash

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining> which is then used to make the large round key

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Crupti> kk

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Crupti> @zpajk To conclude, I think that if the very complex VerusHash v2 is "heavy" on anything, then it's the Intel SIMD intrinsic functions. More precisely, _mm_clmulepi64_si128, _mm_shuffle_epi8, _mm_aesenc_si128 (that's the Haraka 128 SIMD function), _mm_unpacklo_epi32, _mm_unpackhi_epi32, and finally _mm_mulhrs_epi16.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Crupti> @Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Crupti> These functions are called repeatetly every hash.

Author: Gateway#3763
Content: [dscrdvrsc] <Chris - Monkins1010 LOUD Mining> luckily ARM  has intrinsic too..  pmull == clmulepi64. and aes .. which is why the rockxhip gets  1mh/s and the raspberry pi without them is 60kh/s
